item.title: Conic Gradients
item.description: Conic gradients are gaining popularity for their soothing and eye-catching nature. You can eyeball them, but here’s a site that has curated some good-looking ones: https://www.conic.style/

item.title: Opportunities in life come through people
item.description: For us Introverts, it feels more safe to be alone working on our projects, but we need to avoid this comfort and seek connection with others. Humans are social beings
item.content:encoded:
For us Introverts, it feels more safe to be alone working on our projects, but we need to avoid this comfort and seek connection with others.

Humans are social beings

item.title: Sony A6700
item.description: Great camera in theory, but in practice it overheats in warm conditions while doing long (45-minute) recording sessions. I love the image quality I can get with this in S LOG 3 with 4:4:2, but I was spoiled by not having to think about this with my Sony ZV-E10. I don’t think I can recommend it for people who need a camera for shooting real video or live-streaming.
item.content:encoded: Great camera in theory, but in practice it overheats in warm conditions while doing long (45-minute) recording sessions. I love the image quality I can get with this in S LOG 3 with 4:4:2, but I was spoiled by not having to think about this with my Sony ZV-E10. I don’t think I can recommend it for people who need a camera for shooting real video or live-streaming.

item.title: The Ground Up Show

item.content:encoded:
Podcast hosted by Matt D’Avella

Link

item.title: Get your reps in
item.description: You have to do a bunch of shitty work before you will do good work. It’s about getting your reps in, and there really aren’t shortcuts. This idea was taken from an interview on The Ground Up Show. I thought it was especially interesting. We often don’t do things for fear of them being bad, but if we change our mindset to “at the beginning it will be bad, we just need to work through the bad period,” then it’s much easier to get started. Shitty work at the beginning is unavoidable
item.content:encoded:
You have to do a bunch of shitty work before you will do good work. It’s about getting your reps in, and there really aren’t shortcuts. This idea was taken from an interview on The Ground Up Show. I thought it was especially interesting. We often don’t do things for fear of them being bad, but if we change our mindset to “at the beginning it will be bad, we just need to work through the bad period,” then it’s much easier to get started.

Shitty work at the beginning is unavoidable

item.title: How to Pair a Sony Bluetooth Remote
item.description: I always forget how to pair the Bluetooth remote to my Sony A6700 / Sony ZV-E10, so I wrote up the instructions in case I forget again (as I likely will): Go into the pairing screen on the camera itself Hold the Shutter (Still Photo) Button and the Zoom In Buttons on the remote for a few seconds and the camera will detect the remote. From there, make sure Bluetooth Remote Control is enabled in the Camera’s settings Sony ZV-E10
item.content:encoded:
I always forget how to pair the Bluetooth remote to my Sony A6700 / Sony ZV-E10, so I wrote up the instructions in case I forget again (as I likely will):

  • Go into the pairing screen on the camera itself
  • Hold the Shutter (Still Photo) Button and the Zoom In Buttons on the remote for a few seconds and the camera will detect the remote.
  • From there, make sure Bluetooth Remote Control is enabled in the Camera’s settings

Sony ZV-E10

item.title: The power of following-up
item.description: By following up, you show that you’re serious and that you actually care. You’re not just bulk-emailing a bunch of people, fishing for interest. You care about the people and the relationship enough to keep it moving. Follow-up
item.content:encoded:
By following up, you show that you’re serious and that you actually care. You’re not just bulk-emailing a bunch of people, fishing for interest. You care about the people and the relationship enough to keep it moving.

Follow-up

item.title: AI Image Generation
item.description: This week, I played around with Adobe Firefly and Midjourney. My initial impression is that Midjourney produces better images, but Adobe Firefly comes free with Creative Cloud. So far, I don’t think the images produced by Firefly are good enough to stand the eye test, but I think some of the images from Midjourney do.
item.content:encoded:
This week, I played around with Adobe Firefly and Midjourney. My initial impression is that Midjourney produces better images, but Adobe Firefly comes free with Creative Cloud.

So far, I don’t think the images produced by Firefly are good enough to stand the eye test, but I think some of the images from Midjourney do.

item.title: 30 Day Challenges
item.description: Matt D’Avella’s Formula for doing this: I read/translate this as: Why did I want to do this? What research did I do before jumping into this? What was my initial plan for success? What was I worried about prior to starting? What obstacles did I encounter? Was there someone I could reach out to when things got hard? (Optional) What did I learn that changed my approach and got me through said challenges? From there things got significantly easier What was the result? What did I learn? How am I changed, and would I recommend that others try this?
item.content:encoded:
Matt D’Avella’s Formula for doing this:

I read/translate this as:

  1. Why did I want to do this?
  2. What research did I do before jumping into this?
  3. What was my initial plan for success?
    • What was I worried about prior to starting?
  4. What obstacles did I encounter?
  5. Was there someone I could reach out to when things got hard? (Optional)
  6. What did I learn that changed my approach and got me through said challenges?
  7. From there things got significantly easier
  8. What was the result?
  9. What did I learn?
  10. How am I changed, and would I recommend that others try this?

item.title: A habit does not have to be impressive for it to be useful
item.description: An idea pulled from James Clear’s The Surprising Benefits of Journaling One Sentence Every Day I would argue that it’s easier to get started and get committed to unimpressive habits. Once the habit is formed, you can decide if it’s worth intensifying or not. Meta Habits
item.content:encoded:
An idea pulled from James Clear’s The Surprising Benefits of Journaling One Sentence Every Day

I would argue that it’s easier to get started and get committed to unimpressive habits. Once the habit is formed, you can decide if it’s worth intensifying or not.

Meta

Habits
